target_learner.profile: Content is designed for students who may be studying alone at home, have low confidence, are scared of failing, and for whom time is not a luxury. Target students often have test anxiety and fear making mistakes. Feedback must be encouraging, not intimidating.
target_learner.key_difference: This differs greatly from well-supported motivated students or instructors. Always evaluate with the struggling, anxious, time-limited student in mind.

principle.name: ORGANIZED
principle.description: Well chunked, scaffolded, and aligned with learning outcomes

common_issues.issue: Chunks too large for target learner
Scaffolding: complex items added too early
Alignment: tangents not relevant to learning outcomes

principle.name: CONCISE
principle.description: Uses simplest words and clearest explanations to convey concepts
principle.motto: "It's done when nothing more can be removed."

principle.name: PRECISE
principle.description: Uses words accurately, avoiding synonyms/homonyms, vague references

principle.name: INTERACTIVE
principle.description: Keeps students engaged with frequent short activities (every 3-5 minutes)

component.name: Framing text
component.description: 100-150 words with key definitions and terminology
component.purpose: Set up the lesson and provide conceptual foundation

component.name: Animated figure
component.note: OUT OF SCOPE for text review
component.description: 2-3 min with 3-5 scenes, narrated captions, 1-3 brief embedded questions
component.scope: NOT reviewed by text reviewers - handled separately

component.name: Follow-up text
component.description: Additional definitions or explanations after animated figure

component.name: Follow-up questions
component.purpose: Reinforce concepts, address misconceptions, build skill

component.name: Brief summary
component.description: Few-sentence bulleted summary of key ideas and terms

lesson_types.type: Provides initial "anchor" experience before core concept
Teaches the main concept (may be two core lessons for complex subjects)
Provides further details, complexities, detailed examples

rule.title: No Synonyms
rule.description: Create ONE term for each concept and use exclusively
rule.good_example: Choose one term (e.g., "mean") and stick with it throughout
rule.rationale: Synonyms create cognitive load and potential confusion about whether two terms mean the same thing or different things

rule.title: No Homonyms
rule.description: Avoid same word for two different concepts
rule.bad_example: "The function's points are plotted. A key point is that the function's output is never negative."
rule.good_example: "The function's points are plotted. Notice that the function's output is never negative."
rule.rationale: Using "point" for both coordinate pairs and "important fact" creates ambiguity

rule.title: Simple Sentences
rule.bad_example: When planning a road trip, a first step is to check the tires
rule.good_example: Planning a trip involves several steps. The first step is to check the tires.
rule.rationale: Introductory clauses increase cognitive load and can obscure main idea

rule.title: Explicit Structure
rule.guideline: Use numbered lists if order matters
rule.rationale: Visual structure reduces cognitive load and improves scanability

rule.title: Active Voice (But Passive Sometimes OK)
rule.passive_example: Multiplication is applied first in an expression having both + and *

rule.title: Singular Form
rule.bad_example: All humans have noses (could include multiple noses per human)

rule.title: Avoid Vague References
rule.description: Avoid it, they, this, and other potentially vague references
rule.bad_example: The expression has one term. It uses two variables (it could refer to expression or term)
rule.rationale: Even when not ambiguous, such words increase cognitive load

rule.title: No Lazy Starts
rule.description: Start with real subject, not "There is/are"
rule.bad_example: There is a horizontal asymptote at y = 0
rule.good_example: The graph of f has a horizontal asymptote at y = 0

rule.title: Serial Comma
rule.description: Always use serial (Oxford) comma for clarity

rule.title: Explaining vs. We
rule.when_we_ok: Occasional "we" is OK: "We read f' aloud as f prime"

rule.title: No Pronouns Other Than We/Us
rule.description: Do not use he, she, it, they, or you
rule.exception: You may use "it" when the referent is crystal clear and just mentioned

general_guidelines.guideline: Replace reading with dialog - make content interactive
Answerable directly, perhaps with very minimal calculation
Concise stems (usually one line or at most a few words)

multiple_choice_questions.requirement: Short choices: One word or at most a few words
Factor out common text: Move repeated text from choices to stem
Usually 3 choices: 2 distractors (4 OK if more misconceptions exist, 2 OK if truly no more distractors)

requirement.title: Always explain every choice
requirement.for_right_choice: Explain how to get answer (assume student guessed)

multiple_choice_questions.requirement: Common misconceptions as distractors: Focus on real mistakes, not nonsense
Never say "Correct" or "Incorrect" in explanations (platform does this)

short_answer_questions.requirement: Single precise answer: Reduce ambiguity, indicate format

requirement.title: Two Hints Minimum (MANDATORY)
requirement.description: Authors MUST provide at least two general hints and may provide a series. Students reveal hints one at a time in series order.

requirement.title: Hints Must Concretely Lead (CRITICAL)
requirement.description: Each hint must explicitly lead students closer to the correct answer, usually concretely. Follow-up questions are considered "reading", not homework. Think of a tutor teaching while having the student predict next steps. Err on the side of helping.

principles.principle: Each hint moves closer to solution

detailed_example.question: Evaluate 3 + 4 * 7 - 2
detailed_example.hint1: * has highest precedence, so start with 4 * 7
detailed_example.hint2: 3 + (4 * 7) - 2 = 3 + 28 - 2. With + and -, evaluate left to right, so evaluate 3 + 28

detailed_example.question: Find d/dx(x) * d/dx(x²)
detailed_example.hint1: Find each derivative separately, then multiply

requirement.rationale: General statements or questions frustrate students studying alone. Without concrete guidance, struggling students give up rather than persist.

requirement.title: Never Suggest Student Made Error
requirement.description: Don't create hints that suggest the student made an error, like "Remember to multiply first" or "Include one place after the decimal point". Students may assume the hint is based on their attempted answer and think the system is incorrectly faulting their work.
requirement.guideline: General hints should be obviously general and simply lead students a step toward the answer.

requirement.title: Never Redirect to Other Content
requirement.description: NEVER say "Read XYZ and try again." Such hints are demoralizing. The hint series should be self-contained and not refer students elsewhere.
requirement.exception: A hint may refer to a figure in explaining how to obtain the answer: "In the figure above, count the items in the red box and multiply by 5." But NOT: "The above figure has a clue. Can you find that clue?"

requirement.title: Declarative Form, Not Questions
requirement.description: Hints written as questions could lead to further confusion or be too broad. Aim for writing hints in declarative form instead.

follow_up_questions_design.guideline: Look at homework/quiz questions to prepare students

alignment.step: Create exam-worthy questions for learning outcomes
Create quiz questions to prepare for exams
Create homework questions to prepare for quizzes
Create lessons to prepare for homework

author_must_know.requirement: Know what KSAs (Knowledge, Skills, Abilities) the lesson covers
See relevant homework and quiz questions
Stay focused on KSAs and homework questions

common_mistakes.title: Seven Common Authoring Mistakes (FLAG AS HIGH SEVERITY)
common_mistakes.description: These mistakes frequently occur in follow-up question design and significantly impact student learning. Flag aggressively when detected.

mistake.description: More than 10 questions in a single lesson's follow-up section
mistake.impact: Overwhelms students and violates the 5-10 question guideline

mistake.pattern: Taking big jumps between questions (not building simple to harder)
mistake.description: Questions don't progressively scaffold - sudden difficulty increases
mistake.impact: Students cannot bridge conceptual gaps, leading to confusion and frustration
mistake.flag_when: Question N requires skills not developed in questions 1 through N-1

mistake.description: Only calculation/procedural questions, no "why" or understanding questions
mistake.impact: Students learn procedures without understanding, cannot transfer knowledge
mistake.flag_when: All questions are computational with no conceptual reasoning

mistake.pattern: Forgetting to address common mistakes or misconceptions
mistake.description: Questions don't explicitly target known student errors
mistake.impact: Students don't confront and correct their misconceptions
mistake.guideline: Authors should think of common errors from teaching experience

mistake.pattern: Too much calculation (these aren't homework problems)
mistake.impact: Follow-up questions should be "reading" not homework - quick checks of understanding
mistake.flag_when: Questions take more than 1-2 minutes of calculation

mistake.pattern: Combining too many things at once
mistake.description: Single questions testing multiple unrelated concepts simultaneously
mistake.impact: Students cannot isolate what they don't understand
mistake.guideline: Build concepts separately first, then combine in later questions

mistake.pattern: Unnecessary complexity detracting from question's main point
mistake.description: Complex setup or numbers when simple would suffice
mistake.impact: Cognitive load on irrelevant details obscures the concept being taught
mistake.example: Using f(x) = 3x³ - 2x² + 5x - 7 when f(x) = x² would demonstrate the concept

structure.location: Appear in framing text between tags
structure.explain: Explain what something is, not what it does
structure.one_per_statement: Only one term per definition statement

when_to_require.title: REQUIREMENT: Flag as Severity 4 if key mathematical terms introduced in this module are used without definition
when_to_require.rationale: Students studying alone need explicit definitions of all technical terminology

prerequisite_exception.title: PREREQUISITE KNOWLEDGE EXCEPTION
prerequisite_exception.description: Before flagging a missing definition, consider standard Calculus 2 pedagogical progression

how_to_identify.step: Examine the module title and learning objectives to determine the PRIMARY topic being taught
Ask: "What foundational concepts would students need to ALREADY know to learn this primary topic?"
If a term is a BUILDING BLOCK for the primary topic (not the topic itself), it is likely prerequisite knowledge

case.type: NEW terms specific to this module
case.action: Flag as Severity 4 if missing definition
case.example: In a "Power Series" module, flag "radius of convergence", "interval of convergence", "ratio test"

case.action: Flag ONCE per term as Severity 2 with verification message
case.message: Please verify that '[term]' was defined in a prerequisite Calc 2 module. If not, add definition here.
case.example: In a "Taylor Series" module, flag Calc 2-specific terms like "power series", "convergence test", "series" (if not yet defined in this course)
case.note: Only flag terms that are specific to Calc 2 topics, not general Calc 1 fundamentals

case.action: NEVER flag these - they are universal prerequisites

calc1_fundamentals.note: DO NOT FLAG - taught in Calculus 1

pre_calculus_fundamentals.note: DO NOT FLAG - taught before Calculus

case.critical_instruction: If you are unsure whether a term is Calc 1 vs. Calc 2, DO NOT FLAG IT. False positives waste author time. Only flag when confident the term is NEW to this specific module.

prerequisite_exception.when_uncertain: If uncertain whether a term is new or prerequisite, DO NOT FLAG IT. False positives waste author time. Only flag when confident the term is NEW to this module.

typical_calc2_sequence.note: Use this to determine what's likely prerequisite
typical_calc2_sequence.title: Standard Calculus 2 Textbook Sequence
typical_calc2_sequence.description: If a term would naturally appear BEFORE the current module in a typical Calc 2 textbook, it's likely prerequisite knowledge. Ask: "What chapters would come before this one?"

early_calc2.topic: Techniques of Integration (substitution, by parts, partial fractions, trig sub)
Applications of Integration (area, volume, work, arc length)
Infinite Series (convergence, divergence, geometric series, p-series)

mid_calc2.topic: Convergence Tests (ratio test, root test, comparison test, alternating series test, integral test)
Power Series (radius of convergence, interval of convergence)
Taylor and Maclaurin Series (Taylor polynomials, Taylor's theorem)

late_calc2.topic: Vectors and Space (if included in Calc 2)

application_example.scenario: Reviewing a module titled "Taylor Series Convergence"
application_example.likely_prerequisites: power series, radius of convergence, interval of convergence, ratio test, derivative, series, convergence, limit
application_example.rationale: Taylor series modules typically come AFTER power series modules in textbooks. All these terms would have been covered in earlier chapters.
application_example.do_not_flag: power series, radius of convergence, ratio test (these came before Taylor series)
application_example.flag_only: Terms specific to Taylor series that haven't been introduced yet, like "Taylor polynomial", "Maclaurin series", "Taylor's theorem with remainder"

application_example.scenario: Reviewing a module titled "Ratio Test for Series Convergence"
application_example.likely_prerequisites: series, convergence, divergence, limit, geometric series, p-series
application_example.rationale: Ratio test modules come AFTER basic series introduction but BEFORE power series. Students need to know what series and convergence mean.
application_example.do_not_flag: series, convergence, divergence, limit (introduced earlier in Calc 2)
application_example.flag_only: "ratio test" itself (this is the NEW concept being taught)

decision_framework.step: 1. Identify the module's PRIMARY topic from title/learning objectives
2. Ask: "In a standard Calc 2 textbook, what chapters would come BEFORE this module?"
3. Any terms from those prerequisite chapters should NOT be flagged
4. Only flag terms that are NEW to THIS module or LATER modules
5. When in doubt, DO NOT FLAG - pedagogical sequencing varies between textbooks

examples_usage.guideline: Use simplest example when introducing concepts
examples_usage.progression: Start simple (x²) then move to complex (3x² + 2x + 1)

high_severity.indicator: Missing structural components (framing text, questions, etc.)
Content not aligned with learning outcomes (tangents)
Chunks too large for target learner
Vague pronoun references that create ambiguity
Missing concrete examples for abstract concepts

evaluation_principle.question: Will a student studying alone at home, with low confidence and limited time, be able to understand and succeed with this?
evaluation_principle.instruction: Evaluate all content by asking this question. If the answer is "no" or "uncertain", you have likely found an issue worth flagging.
